-KkCo6caOfh3wcfqkNHp.text: Excellent introduction to machine learning. I don't really recommend taking this as the first class to the program though, unless you have a background in machine learning. Even then, it wasn't so much the content that makes the class difficult, rather the amount of pages you will be writing over the semester (I think I wrote somewhere between 30 and 40 pages for the semester) on top of everything else you have to do. Definitely recommend it. The instructors are awesome as well.

-KkCon5Mw9RS_rHLV-Gc.author: mF5sMVuOtrb72Xz3mHvDNHtFPbI3
-KkCon5Mw9RS_rHLV-Gc.text: It was okay, but David Joyner was awesome. The content is a little light, compared to other courses, but you learn a decent amount. It probably would be best to take this before ML or AI, although it probably won't prepare you much for those.

-KkIEM1d3_5JMXFwiBF7.author: k9HaDxgeYgbV2jcC4ilLP8jL9F32
-KkIEM1d3_5JMXFwiBF7.text: A good course to start the program with, I enjoyed the class a lot more than I expected. The lectures were good and the projects taught the concepts well. I enjoyed it and learned a lot.

-KkIEtUrzP8cHvtT--BD.author: k9HaDxgeYgbV2jcC4ilLP8jL9F32
-KkIEtUrzP8cHvtT--BD.text: A class that rewards hard work and is really oriented around you persuing something you're interested it. This was a very different type of class - only one week of lectures and the rest of it were projects. Probably shouldn't be taken your first semester or two.

-KkNIxVSnUnPJxhiPg2V.author: dUn1x6vYjFTdGjFO4avFwmwUzPf2
-KkNIxVSnUnPJxhiPg2V.text: I took this with SDP as my first two courses during my first semester. Thad and the TAs were excellent in every way. They created challenging but rewarding projects and were very responsive to questions on Piazza. I would recommend taking this with a less difficult class as the projects and material are very time consuming and complex. Also, I had never used Python before, but the class would have been much easier if I had.

-KkNJOmqeV1KNtzOK4uO.author: dUn1x6vYjFTdGjFO4avFwmwUzPf2
-KkNJOmqeV1KNtzOK4uO.text: Alex Orso is an excellent professor. This is a great beginner software course, and I really enjoyed the lectures. There was a final group project at the end in Android that was very time consuming, but other than that the assignments were straightforward for people who know Java.

-KkRiRQ0lRJr1K83mLyu.author: NkyVycvEueeqCT5Ro8lhLpMQqRf2
-KkRiRQ0lRJr1K83mLyu.text:
Very good and passionate instructor. Made good use of Office Hours time. TA's were helpful. 

Make sure you inform instructor early on if one of your project team members is MIA. 

Course was a good review of some of my undergrad work. Very good presentation of Agile and Scrum. The JAVA and Android was a nice change for development tasks. 

Work with your group up front to find strengths and weaknesses. When it is your turn to be the task lead stay on top of it. Having team members in 5 time zones can be a challenge but it gives you a perspective of what it will be like for remote collaboration efforts.

-KkRlLCaak8VG0YkQQXc.author: NkyVycvEueeqCT5Ro8lhLpMQqRf2
-KkRlLCaak8VG0YkQQXc.text:
Don't take this course as your first OMS class. If the intent was a weeding out course this is it. 

It's been 20 years since I took an OS class. The content covered in the first two or three lectures was about the extent my brain could take. Thank goodness you can re-watch the videos. I filled up a spiral notebook in the first 3 weeks. 

At the time I took the class the white papers were "recommended" reading. That should be changed to required reading and you better start reading them daily. Download all of the previous semester(s) mid-term and finals early to get a good idea of what to expect. 

I got a 48 on the mid-term. Ended up withdrawing from the class and was lucky to make it before the deadline somehow. A friend stayed in and ended up with a 57 and got a B! I am sure the class has good content but what a shock as to how much was flowing from the pipe. If you aren't sure about the Adv OS then take the Intro to OS. Both of them count toward the requirement.

-Kkqqws1RXJztSSxZuCO.author: n9qWmy0yVeeJFJHkvgmoczZYTlh1
-Kkqqws1RXJztSSxZuCO.text:
Good concept for a class, but the lectures have almost nothing to do with the projects. The projects are different variations of the same project. There is no code feedback, so you'll have a much easier time if you're already proficient in the language you use. Similarly, if you struggle with the first or second project, you're in trouble because they keep building on the previous and they become harder. Many had to completely start from scratch which can be frustrating. 

There's a lot of writing to be done between assignments/projects/exams and at some point it starts to feel like a lot of bsing. The class has great potential, but lacks a bit in execution.

-Ko8Ar4-kv-3cBYLJMRz.author: mdbNol35vRh7LVGpeOGncBIPgSN2
-Ko8Ar4-kv-3cBYLJMRz.text: This is one of the best courses in this program. It is very well organized, and the professors are probably two of the best in the program. Throughout the course, you will build an AI agent which can solve puzzles used in measuring IQ. You are given the option of using either Python or Java; I advise that you stick with Python, and this is coming from someone who has expert knowledge in Java. You will be writing a ton of reports in this course, with diagrams and all, and you will spend lots of hours coding. Grades are curved at the end, and the professor reiterates that he wants you to learn and not worry about what grade you are going to get. The midterm and final are both take home, but be prepared to put about 20 hours into completing each.

-KqKYFVtzfbGP9V3BVig.author: facebook:10153373113915356
-KqKYFVtzfbGP9V3BVig.text: I like this one. As mentioned in other reviews, it's a good intro to ML, and exposure to many of the libraries you'll likely use again to manipulate data in Python (numpy/pandas). The professor is active and engaged. Lectures good, assignments for the most part good (lots of busywork generating graphs though).

-KqPiR1V5QHGRjg4r3ze.author: VGwn29OLPKf2m1s6TCvpQNqC28u1
-KqPiR1V5QHGRjg4r3ze.text:
This was my first course in OMSCS and it was absolutely brilliant. It set the bar incredibly high for what online classes should be. 

This course should be required to graduate. The workload was very manageable and the lectures very interesting. I had been writing file systems for about 4 years when I took this class and I managed to learn a worthwhile amount.

-KqWLHwIEBRtrWB0NO-_.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWLHwIEBRtrWB0NO-_.text: Course was good, it had a lot of work in Fall 2015 with weekly quiz and multiple projects and 2 exams. Between the lectures, reading and projects, it was about 10-12 hours per week.

-KqWLt5kEUREIRFowevd.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWLt5kEUREIRFowevd.text: in fall 2016 there were no exams and the projects were super interesting. there wasn't a lot of additional reading other than for the completing the projects.

-KqWM8frYk7XMabb7waw.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWM8frYk7XMabb7waw.text: one of the more interesting classes, it required weekly assignments which were due saturday morning and released on saturday. the work was doable, but it was challenging.

-KqWMe2Q0ZUcdp2poCx2.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWMe2Q0ZUcdp2poCx2.text: this class required a lot of work. it also required having a good team. We ended up with a good team initially and picked up some other good members before the end of the semester. it's one of the most time consuming classes taken so far in the program. It was both interesting and rewarding. Learned a lot along the way.

-KqWNN7saWx6hA9ohNlB.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWNN7saWx6hA9ohNlB.text: this class requires a solid understanding of statistics and calculus. if those skills are rough this is a tough class to complete or even understand.

-KqWNd2UfcjJRznAuf4W.author: nolpnDASmPenKisB8ZqXhWTpE6P2
-KqWNd2UfcjJRznAuf4W.text: this class requires a firm knowledge of C. If you haven't use or remember C this class is difficult. Only recommend if you know C.

-KqcnqKT39JBcBxtynK7.author: ABzdUnthZKWxZGqOPz9gAO2UmsT2
-KqcnqKT39JBcBxtynK7.text: This class is very useful. It's somewhat easy if you already have some software development experience. The teamwork was a challenge because some team members aren't as dedicated plus dealing with schedules was a pain

-Kqcp_l4WQgrNLQWb20h.author: ABzdUnthZKWxZGqOPz9gAO2UmsT2
-Kqcp_l4WQgrNLQWb20h.text: This was a challenging class for me even though I've been developing with databases for years. The main reason for this is because some mostly academic topics are covered in depth such as query calculus and algebra. These were completely new topics for me. The rest though was pretty much the same you'd learn in any db class

-Kqi15T9E9KddgRgho-Y.author: vh8uo9EgyiP9hc5clUYvgivWI1m2
-Kqi15T9E9KddgRgho-Y.text: Good course in my opinion. Starts off easy and gets harder at the end. I knew R coming into it which made everything a lot simpler. Definitely a good course to take before you take machine learning. Gives you a background in R, and touches upon the beginnings of machine learning with linear regression.

-Kqi1S4Vt7E0I8Ip32um.author: vh8uo9EgyiP9hc5clUYvgivWI1m2
-Kqi1S4Vt7E0I8Ip32um.text: This was a tough course for me having never been a software developer and knowing no java. Can be extremely time consuming. Luckily when you get teams to work with you are given teams with skills that compliment your own.

-KqkaQG5gjhQSn30bfQ6.author: g59O6MO9OXUNdkQaLOpb2kpZFAG2
-KqkaQG5gjhQSn30bfQ6.text: I took this as my second course for the foundational requirements. You need to spend time on the projects as they are not straightforward. Read all the papers they ask you to read this is needed for the projects and exam!

-KqmiZD8lEVQ0ikoOJ55.author: WX6jvC7UJtTnft9RjWYTckg2Y6D3
-KqmiZD8lEVQ0ikoOJ55.text: Great course... appropriate breadth and depth for this topic. Instructor is excellent, and the TAs did a good job as well. Like most OS courses, it's based on the "C" language so students would be well advised to refresh their existing skills or acquire a solid fundamental familiarity (e. g., syntax, pointers, etc. ) in advance because you will be using them right from the start of the first project assignment. The course will build upon them and explore subjects such as the various forms of IPC, concurrency, etc.

-KrCleGjHHjxG3oFoSKe.author: ExecoHAjrrc7QflEsAyZqfSdQMj1
-KrCleGjHHjxG3oFoSKe.text: This was my first class in OMSCS and I found it very difficult but also very educational. The difficulty for me mostly came from the fact that this class is very theoretical and uses relatively esoteric tools for the projects (WEKA). Even though I got a B in the course (which is considered bottom 50%) I found this class to be excellent prep for CS7646 (Machine Learning for Trading).

-KsPmyIoZ0GjKtG59xYa.author: pvd9rt30O0ScZ5IVb4TrNgAq1eq2
-KsPmyIoZ0GjKtG59xYa.text: This is the BEST class I took. Excellent materials and professor! You need to be very familiar with python, probability, and linear algebra. The homework focus on programming your own functions based on the algorithms discussed in class instead of using existing functions. This really helps you to better understand how these famous algorithms work. Every two weeks I had to submit my programming project, so the time was tight and painful, but l could still handle it and definitely learned so much. I recommend this class to everyone.

-Kur32_Z_L0QZ8N0_Fl-.author: M9tOKm39FWSq4bE9Nj3fVzMgWVH2
-Kur32_Z_L0QZ8N0_Fl-.text:
Fantastically done class! The lectures were great - they used a very accessible metaphor (consistent through the whole class) to explain the different problems to be solved by the OS, and the different roles that OS components would fulfill. 

The projects were challenging, but were presented with just enough guidance to be manageable. Each assignment used Bonnie for autograding, which was exposed to the students and was invaluable during testing. It makes an assignment much less stressful when you have a live view of your grade, before you submit the assignment!

-KvJD_eD2Uan-JtHlUgi.author: e522825c-ab47-4a30-92a8-f5d78f8654d4
-KvJD_eD2Uan-JtHlUgi.text: One of my favorite classes. It's the first course where could throw your efforts into something you find super interesting. The entire course is focused around a project you get to choose. The professor is highly engaged.

-KxPRX86ORwuQONJcVtZ.author: e8ICUxD2kvWf7kOowWPv4qpEUvi1
-KxPRX86ORwuQONJcVtZ.text:
Since students are registering, probably a good time to give a midway review. 

The fact that I hated this course isn't a reflection on the professor or TAs. They did an amazing job. I just really hate theoretical math. Lets be real here, this is a weeder course that is really hard for the sake or being really hard. If you are not good at math theory, you will probably struggle, a lot. Though the homeworks are worth a small portion of the grade (as is the project), I had to spend almost all my free time after work studying and learning concepts just so that I would be semi competent in the tests, and even after all that time, there is a better than not chance that I will be retaking this as I will have gotten a C. 

My biggest recommendations are to look at the material way before hand. At least a few months before, so you get an idea of what you need to learn. Lots of this stuff takes time to understand and you will find that most of the concepts you need to know are things you did years ago in undergrad. Again, unless you are really good with theory, you will probably have to do tons of practice problems to get an idea of what is going on. 

Newer students to the program should take this quickly. It was recommended to me (when the older version of this class was out) to just avoid this in general and go Interactive Intelligence, but I did not listen. I severely regret doing so, as I will be forced to take this until I pass.

alerts.text: OMSCentral is under new management (@martzcodes).  Talk to me on slack in #OMSCentral
